source:
hundreds of children were admitted to hospital last year after being born brain damaged following exposure to alcohol in the womb , alarming new figures have revealed .
in total , 272 youngsters left disabled by foetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalised in england over the past 12 months , according to data from the official health and social care information centre .
but the actual number affected by their mother ' s drinking could be far greater , experts have warned .
warning : new figures show that 272 youngsters left disabled by foetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalised in england over the past 12 months , according to the official health and social care information centre
research by the world health organisation suggests that at least one in 100 babies born in the uk could suffer learning , behavioural and physical problems such as deformed limbs because of exposure to alcohol , according to the sunday people .
that equates to about 7,500 every year .
elizabeth mitchell , of the national organisation for foetal alchol syndrome , told reporter nicola fifield : ` children born with the syndrome do n't get better .
` it is an enormous problem and one that is terribly sad and vastly under-diagnosed . '
tip of the iceberg : research by the world health organisation suggests that at least one in 100 babies born in the uk could suffer learning and behavioural problems because of exposure to alcohol in the womb
one teenager who was born with foetal alcohol syndrome is 15-year-old niamh brown .
she needs help getting dressed , has no sense of danger and will never be able to live independently .
niamh was three when her adoptive parents julia and simon first noticed something was wrong .
she stuggled at playschool , having difficulty holding a pencil and paying attention .
two years later , at the age of five , niamh was diagnosed with foetal alcohol syndrome from her birth mother 's drinking .
in 2007 , julia and simon set up the foetal alcohol spectrum disorder trust to help others .
other medical issues associated with alcohol consumption during pregnancy include problems with the liver , kidneys and heart , cerebral palsy , sight loss and epilepsy .
pregnant women are advised by the government not to drink alcohol .
if they do , the maximum consumption recommended is up to two units no more than twice a week .
but ms mitchell believes the guidance should be changed so that women are advised not to drink at all during pregnancy .
summary:
The passage discusses the issue of Foetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) in the UK. According to the Official Health and Social Care Information Centre, 272 children were hospitalized due to FAS over the past 12 months. However, experts warn that the actual number could be much higher. The World Health Organization's research suggests that about 7,500 babies in the UK could suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure in the womb.

One example of a child affected by FAS is 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who requires assistance with daily activities, has no sense of danger, and will never be able to live independently. She was diagnosed with FAS at the age of five, after her adoptive parents noticed her struggles at playschool.

The passage also mentions other medical issues associated with alcohol consumption during pregnancy, such as problems with the liver, kidneys, heart, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. Pregnant women are currently advised by the government not to exceed more than two units of alcohol twice a week, but Elizabeth Mitchell, from

The passage highlights the alarming issue of foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) in England, with 272 children hospitalized due to brain damage from in-utero alcohol exposure in the past year. Experts warn that the actual number affected could be much higher. Research suggests that at least one in 100 UK babies could suffer learning, behavioural, and physical problems due to prenatal alcohol exposure, equating to approximately 7,500 cases annually. FAS is a severe, lifelong condition that is often under-diagnosed. The passage also mentions other health issues linked to alcohol consumption during pregnancy and the current government advice on alcohol consumption for pregnant women.

summary:
Here's a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information:

The passage discusses the alarming impact of alcohol consumption during pregnancy on children in the UK. Key points include:

1. 272 children with foetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalized in England last year.

2. The World Health Organization estimates that at least 1 in 100 UK babies (about 7,500 annually) may suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure in the womb.

3. Foetal alcohol syndrome is described as an enormous, sad, and under-diagnosed problem that doesn't improve over time.

4. The passage provides an example of a 15-year-old girl with foetal alcohol syndrome who requires assistance and will never live independently.

5. Other medical issues associated with prenatal alcohol exposure are mentioned, including liver, kidney, and heart problems.

6. Current UK government advice allows pregnant women to drink up to two units twice a week, but some experts believe complete abstinence should be recommended.

summary: Hundreds of children in England were hospitalized last year due to fetal alcohol syndrome, a condition caused by exposure to alcohol in the womb. The official number is 272, but experts believe the actual count could be higher. Research suggests that at least 1% of babies born in the UK may suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical disabilities due to prenatal alcohol exposure. This equates to around 7,500 babies annually. Fetal alcohol syndrome is a lifelong condition, and affected children often require assistance with daily tasks and struggle with cognitive and physical impairments. The World Health Organization's research highlights the severity of the issue, and experts advocate for stricter guidelines to discourage alcohol consumption during pregnancy.

summary:
Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

In England, 272 children were hospitalized last year due to being born with Foetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS), a condition caused by exposure to alcohol in the womb. Experts warn that the actual number of affected children could be much higher. Research suggests that at least 1 in 100 babies born in the UK (approximately 7,500 per year) may suffer from learning, behavioural, and physical problems due to maternal alcohol consumption. Children born with FAS do not get better and may require lifelong care, as seen in the case of 15-year-old Niamh Brown. The condition can lead to a range of medical issues, including problems with the liver, kidneys, heart, and sight loss. The government advises pregnant women not to drink, with a recommended maximum consumption of up to 2 units, no more than twice a week, but some experts believe the guidance should be strengthened to advise complete abstinence during pregnancy.

summary:
Here is a concise summary of the passage:

* 272 children with foetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalized in England over the past 12 months, according to the Health and Social Care Information Centre.
* Experts warn that the actual number affected by maternal drinking could be far greater, with the World Health Organisation estimating that at least 1 in 100 babies born in the UK may suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to exposure to alcohol in the womb.
* This equates to approximately 7,500 babies per year.
* Foetal alcohol syndrome is a lifelong condition with no cure, and can cause a range of problems including learning difficulties, behavioral issues, and physical deformities.
* Pregnant women are currently advised to limit their alcohol consumption to 2 units, no more than twice a week, but some experts believe that the guidance should be changed to advise against drinking altogether during pregnancy.

summary: In England, 272 children were hospitalized in the past year due to Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS), a disability caused by alcohol exposure in the womb. This number is likely much lower than the actual number of children affected, as research suggests that at least 1 in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure. FAS can cause lifelong disabilities, such as difficulty learning, holding a pencil, and paying attention. Other medical issues associated with alcohol consumption during pregnancy include problems with the liver, kidneys, heart, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. The government advises pregnant women to avoid alcohol, but some experts believe that women should not drink at all during pregnancy.

summary: Hundreds of children were hospitalized last year in England due to brain damage from foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), with 272 cases reported, though the actual number may be higher. Research indicates that at least one in 100 UK babies could suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to prenatal alcohol exposure, equating to about 7,500 affected babies annually. Elizabeth Mitchell from the National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome highlights the severity and under-diagnosis of the issue. A case example is 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who has severe disabilities due to FAS. The government advises pregnant women to limit alcohol intake, but some experts, like Mitchell, advocate for complete abstinence during pregnancy.
